div1.head: Report: Summary of Progress for Yellow Fever for the Six Months Ending June 1, 1924, by [Henry Rose Carter?]
div1.p: /LC

Summary of Progress for Yellow Fever
for the Six Months Ending June 1, 1924.

During the six months ending June 1/24 the editor has seen only
one paper in the medical press which, in his opinion, may markedly in-
crease our knowledge of yellow fever.

This is by Hoffmann (1) of Havana, reporting lime casts as of well
nigh constant occurrence in the kidneys (in the convoluted tubules and
the loops of Houle especially) of men dead of yellow fever.

His work was done on old material from autopsies made in Havana
in 1905 to 1908, mainly or exclusively by Guiteras. Specimens from 30
cases were examined and in nearly all lime casts were found; a later com-
munication (1b) states that “although only very limited material was a-
vailable”---“these casts were found in 24 out of 28 cases without any
difficulty in the first preparation.” He used haematoxylin as a stain.

Hoffmann has not found lime casts in the kidneys of those dead
of other diseases than yellow fever except in cases of bichloride of mer-
cury poisoning and in the paper last quoted. He especially notes their
non-occurrence in Weil's disease: black-water fever: malaria and relapsing
fever, some of which diseases may give autopsies confusable with yellow
fever. They were found also in dogs or rather in a dog inoculated with Leptospira icteroides,
but not in guinea pigs.

Hoffmann regards these casts as being much the most distinctive
sign of yellow fever found at autopsy--as well nigh pathognomonic. How-
ever this may be, if these findings (including the absence of these casts
in other diseases possibly confusable with yellow fever) are confirmed
there is no question but that he has made an extremely valuable con-
tribution to the pathology of that disease: And one of no less value to
the sanitarian also, giving him a more certain, or it may be a certain,
differential diagnosis for this disease after death.

Hoffmann suggests that possibly these same casts may be found
found
-2-
in the urine of yellow fever patients. If so, and if this be confined
to yellow fever, thissuch a determination would be as valuable to the clini-
cian in the differential diagnosis during life as would be the presence
of these casts in the kidneys after death to the pathologist. It would
be equally valuable to the sanitarian, indeed more so, than the post mor-
tem determination as many cases suspected of being yellow fever are seen
which do not come to autopsy.

The existence of lime casts in the kidney should admit of ready
verification as old yellow fever material is abundant and available for
examination in many places and reports on this matter should even now be
appearing. The examination of the urine for lime casts is possible only
where yellow fever is occurring and this is without doubt being made in
such places. We await the reports from both sets of investigators with
much interest and some impatience.
A few other articles appearing during in the six months specified should be noted:

An article by Connor (2) is valuable, it may be counted invaluable
to the field sanitarian, in that it gathers into one article the detail ne-
cessary and advisable for the elimination of yellow fever by control of
the breeding places of its insect vector. It summarizes Connor's exper-
ience in yellow fever campaigns for the past seven years in Spanish America
and gives in one paper the digested substance of many reports and scattered
articles.

There were two papers published, bearing on the still disputed ques-
tion: the identity of Leptospira icteroides with the causative organism of
yellow Fever: One of them by Froes (3) writing from Brazil, notes the ex-
tremely close resemblance between yellow fever in man and the experimental
infection with Leptospira icteroides taking special account of the post-mortem
appearances in each case. This does not agree with the observations of
Hoffmann of Havana as published about two years ago (See the Summary for
Summary for
-3-
Yellow Fever from Oct. 1/22 to April 1/23: Page 455 this Volume). (Foot
note)

(Foot note): It does, however, agree with a recent note of the same
writer (Hoffmann). He writes (10: “Though my study” of yellow fever in man
“has a purely anatomical character, the results are now in accordance with
the Leptospira icteroides as the aetiological agent of yellow fever. After
my first study there remained several doubts which now have been fully ex-
plained.” Note too his finding of lime casts, which in men he considers
almost pathognomonic of yellow fever, in dogs infected with Leptospira ic-
teroides. (End of foot note).

On the same lines as Froes--i. e. as tending to confirm the identi-
ty of these organisms, Noguchi (4) collects a number of reports of Pfeiffer
reactions of cultures of Leptospira icteroides and the serum of men who
had recently recovered from yellow fever, some made by himself and some by
others. The reactions were almost all positive, three negative ones be-
ing reported in this series of 52--all 3 of which were during his first
work in Guayaquil in 1918.

The reactions were positive for convalescents in Brazil with
strains of organisms from Ecuador: Mexico and Peru. See also in this con-
nection similar results reported by Perez Grovas of Mexico (Summary for
Yellow Fever for six months ending Oct. 1/23: P. 721 this volume). The
reactions of these men, positive to Leptospira icteroides were negative to
Leptospira icterohemorrhagica whenever the latter was tried: It was not
tried in every case.

Both of these last two articles give data in favor of Leptospira
icteroides being the causative organism of yellow fever and the editor
has for some time accepted it as such. It may not have been quite logical
to do so without reserve as a number of men as well qualified to judge as
as
-4-
himself are not convinced of it. Yet he thinks all who have kept in
close touch with this matter will admit that the evidence for the causal
role of this organism has been increasing steadily, if not spectacularly,
since this was first claimed for it by Noguchi in 1918; so too he thinks
has increased the number of men who accept it. In his judgment he causal
role of this organism in yellow fever is at present rather generally, but
by no means universally accepted. If the statements of Hoffmann quoted in this
summary imply that the Havana School is prepared to accept this doctrine,
there will be very few left to oppose it.

and Hygiene (London): No. 17: Vol. XXVII: pp. 235-240.

2: Connor, M. E. Suggestions for Developing a Campaign to
Control Yellow Fever. Am. Journal. Trop. Med. 4: 277, 1924.

3: Froes, J. A. G. Etiologia de Febre Amarella. Medicina Bra-

4: Noguchi, Hideyo. The Pfeiffer Reaction in Yellow Fever.
